intro: Lappula texana var. foliosa, commonly known as Texas lappula, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is a member of the Papaveraceae family, which includes poppies and related species. The plant features basal leaves that are typically lobed or deeply divided, and its flowers are small, yellowish-green, and clustered in umbels. It thrives in dry, sandy soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed areas. The species is characterized by its distinctive leaf morphology and is of interest to botanists and ecologists studying plant adaptation in arid environments.
